0.question: What power was granted to the states by the Articles of Confederation but not by the Constitution?
choices: Coining money
Authorizing constitutional amendments
Having representation in Congress
Appealing to the president to adjudicate disputes
0.initial_response: The Articles of Confederation granted the states the power to declare war, while the Constitution granted that power to the federal government.

8.question: The exclusionary rule was established to
choices: create "separate but equal" facilities to facilitate racial segregation
allow private organizations to restrict their memberships
limit the government's ability to use illegally obtained evidence
deny control of interstate commerce to the states
8.initial_response:
prevent the government from using illegally obtained evidence against a defendant.

The exclusionary rule is a legal principle that holds that evidence obtained through illegal means is not admissible in a criminal trial. The rule is meant to deter law enforcement from engaging in illegal activities, and to protect the rights of defendants. The exclusionary rule has been controversial, and has been the subject of numerous Supreme Court cases.

9.question: The opinions of congressional committees often fail to accurately mirror public opinion because
choices: the membership of committees often overrepresents constituencies with the greatest stake in the committee's business
most committees are too small to include representatives of all popular opinions
the minority party controls nearly half of all committees
committee members often lose track of their constituents' priorities because of their frequent contact with special-interest lobbyists
9.initial_response: the committees are not representative of the public. The committees are typically made up of members of the same political party, which can result in a biased perspective. Additionally, the committees often have ulterior motives, such as advancing their own political agendas, which can distort their views.

10.question: Congress would be required to use the "elastic clause" of the Constitution to
choices: change citizenship requirements
impose workplace safety standards
increase tax rates
authorize the treasury to print money
10.initial_response: pass a law that would allow the government to do this.

11.question: The House Rules Committee is considered among the most powerful in the House of Representatives because it has great power over the
choices: ethical conduct of House members
selection of federal judges
number of subcommittees that a standing committee may establish at any given time
scheduling of votes and the conditions under which bills are debated and amended
11.initial_response:
legislative agenda. The committee is responsible for deciding which bills will be considered by the full House, and it can prevent bills from reaching the floor for a vote. The committee also sets the rules for debate on the House floor.

The House Rules Committee is chaired by the majority party's floor leader in the House of Representatives. The committee has nine members from the majority party and six members from the minority party.

12.question: In the past decade many states have moved forward the date of their presidential primary elections in an effort to
choices: minimize the cost of running the election
convince the national government to move forward the date of the general election
restrict the number of entrants in the presidential race
increase the significance of their election results
12.initial_response:
increase their influence in the presidential nomination process.

The date of a state's presidential primary election is set by state law and can be as early as February or as late as June. In the past, most primaries were held in the spring, but in recent years, many states have moved their primaries to earlier in the year in an effort to increase their influence in the presidential nomination process.

The first presidential primaries were held in New Hampshire in 1920. In the years since, the primary calendar has shifted and changed as states have jockeyed for position. The result has been a front-loading of the primary calendar, with more and more states holding their primaries earlier in the year.

The trend began in the 1970s, when a number of states moved their primaries to March in an effort to increase their influence. In 1976, for example, 22 states held their primaries in March, compared to just four in February and six in April.

The trend accelerated in the 1980s and 1990s, as more and more states moved their primaries to February in an effort to be the first in the nation. In 1992, for example, 12 states held their primaries in February, compared to just four in March and two in April.

The trend has continued in the 2000s, with even more states moving their primaries to February. In 2008, for example, 24 states held their primaries in February, compared to just four in March and two in April.

The result of all this front-loading is that the presidential nomination process has become much shorter and more compressed than it was in the past. In the past, the nomination process often lasted for months, or even years. Today, it is often over in just a few weeks.

The front-loading of the primary calendar has had a number of consequences. One is that it has made it difficult for candidates who are not well-known or well-funded to compete. Another is that it has made it difficult for candidates who do not do well in the early primaries to recover.

The front-loading of the primary calendar has also had a number of unintended consequences. One is that it has made it difficult for candidates who are not well-known or well-funded to compete. Another is that it has made it difficult for candidates who do not do well in the early primaries to recover.

The front-loading of the primary calendar has also made it difficult for candidates who are not well-known or well-funded to compete.

13.question: Ruled unconstitutional in 1983, the legislative veto had allowed
choices: the executive branch to veto legislation approved by Congress
federal district courts to overturn legislation
the president to veto state laws
Congress to nullify resolutions approved by the executive branch
13.initial_response:
Congress to overturn executive branch actions without going through the formal amendment process.

The court ruled that the veto was unconstitutional because it violated the separation of powers between the executive and legislative branches.

The ruling was a major blow to Congress, which had used the veto to overturn a wide range of executive branch actions, including regulations, executive orders, and agency decisions.

The ruling has had a major impact on the relationship between the executive and legislative branches, and has led to a significant increase in the power of the executive branch.

14.question: In "Federalist No. 10," James Madison argues that a federal system of government reduces the danger of political factions by
choices: creating insurmountable obstacles to the founding of factions
making it difficult for one faction to gain the power necessary to govern
requiring equal representation of all factions within the government
restricting factional political activity to the state level only
14.initial_response: dividing power between the national and state governments.

15.question: The boundary lines of congressional districts must be redrawn every 10 years to
choices: reflect population shifts indicated by the national census
guarantee the turnover of the majority of congressional seats
make sure each state's congressional delegation exactly mirrors its residents' party affiliations
determine which party's leader will be named Speaker of the House
15.initial_response:
reflect changes in population.

The process of redrawing congressional districts is called redistricting.

16.question: Each of the two main political parties of the United States is organized
choices: as a single party with a presence at the national level only
into a federal structure in which state and local parties have no power
as a relatively independent organization that exists at all levels of government
in a top-down fashion, so that instructions are dispersed from the national level to the state and local levels
16.initial_response: around a set of core beliefs. The Republican Party's core beliefs include a commitment to limited government, individual liberty, and free markets. The Democratic Party's core beliefs include a commitment to social and economic justice, a strong role for government in ensuring equality of opportunity, and a belief in a "safety net" of government programs to protect the most vulnerable members of society.

17.question: The origination clause of the Constitution states that
choices: the Bill of Rights must not be infringed upon by any state legislature
Congress and the president must jointly create the annual federal budget
revenue bills must be initiated in the House of Representatives
the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction over all constitutional matters
17.initial_response:
the legislative power of the federal government shall be vested in Congress, which shall consist of a Senate and House of Representatives.

The origination clause is found in Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution. It states that "All Bills for raising Revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives." This means that any bill that would raise taxes or spending must originate in the House of Representatives. The Senate may then propose amendments to the bill, but the House must approve any changes before the bill can become law.

18.question: What is the primary reason that the committees in the House of Representatives are more influential than they are in the Senate?
choices: The difference in size between the two chambers means that more work is done on the floor in the Senate and more work is done in committees in the House.
The Senate as a whole has confirmation powers that the House does not have.
Members are appointed to the committee in the House but are elected to committees in the Senate.
A member of any party can serve a committee in the House, but only major party members can serve on committees in the Senate.
18.initial_response: The primary reason that the committees in the House of Representatives are more influential than they are in the Senate is that the House of Representatives has more members.

19.question: The Commerce Clause of the Constitution has been used to
choices: release detainees from prison following unlawful arrest
maintain the navy
increase the power of the national government
veto legislative bills of attainder
19.initial_response:
justify the federal government's involvement in a wide variety of regulatory programs.

The Commerce Clause of the Constitution gives the federal government the power to regulate interstate and foreign commerce. This power has been used to justify the federal government's involvement in a wide variety of regulatory programs, including environmental protection, consumer protection, and antitrust enforcement.

20.question: Republican candidates for president who tend to be more successful in the primaries tend to be more conservative than rank-and-file Republicans because
choices: moderate Republicans are less likely than conservative Republicans to gain widespread support in the general election
most moderate Republicans have approved of the Democratic presidential candidate
most rank-and-file Republicans do not care whether their party's nominee shares their political views
party activists, whose political participation is disproportionate to their numbers, tend to be very conservative
20.initial_response: they are more appealing to the party's base voters.

21.question: A "motion for cloture" is used to
choices: send a bill back to the House
override a presidential veto in the House
amend an appropriations bill in the House
end a filibuster and force a vote on a bill in the Senate
21.initial_response: end debate on a particular topic in the United States Senate. A motion for cloture requires a three-fifths majority vote in order to be passed. If the motion for cloture is passed, then debate on the topic is ended and a vote is taken on the issue.

22.question: The relative stability of American public policy is achieved largely through
choices: cooperation between the two major political parties
judicial activism
the constitutional fragmentation of power
affirmative action programs
22.initial_response:
the separation of powers.

The separation of powers is a principle of the American government that ensures that no one branch of government has too much power. This principle is achieved through a system of checks and balances, in which each branch of government can limit the power of the other branches. The separation of powers is an important part of the American system of government because it helps to prevent any one branch from becoming too powerful and abusing its authority.

23.question: A sound bite would most likely be used during a presidential election in order to
choices: avoid "horse race" politics
provide the audience with a candidate's view in a limited amount of time
reduce the amount of negative advertising used
ensure a candidate is presented in the best light
23.initial_response:
A sound bite would most likely be used during a presidential election in order to

provide a quick and memorable way for a candidate to communicate their platform to the public.

24.question: The Dred Scott decision of 1857 was overturned by the
choices: Plessy v. Ferguson decision
Missouri Compromise
Jim Crow laws
Fourteenth Amendment
24.initial_response: Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution in 1865. The Thirteenth Amendment abolished slavery in the United States.

25.question: An open primary is a primary election in which
choices: voters registered as "independents" may not vote
candidates do not specify the office for which they are running
voters may register at their polling place on election day
voters may vote in the election of a party other than the one to which they are registered
25.initial_response:
any registered voter can choose which party's primary to vote in, regardless of their party affiliation.

An open primary is a primary election in which any registered voter can choose which party's primary to vote in, regardless of their party affiliation. This type of primary is often used in an effort to increase participation in the electoral process and to allow voters to have a greater say in who their party's nominee will be.

26.question: The Supreme Court has used the practice of selective incorporation to
choices: limit the number of appeals filed by defendants in state courts
extend voting rights to racial minorities and women
apply most Bill of Rights protections to state law
hasten the integration of public schools
26.initial_response:
incorporate the Bill of Rights into the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

The Fourteenth Amendment states, in relevant part, that "[n]o State shall . . . deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law." U.S. Const. amend. XIV, sec. 1. The Supreme Court has interpreted this provision to incorporate most of the protections in the Bill of Rights.

The Supreme Court has not incorporated all of the protections in the Bill of Rights. For example, the Third Amendment, which protects against the quartering of soldiers in private homes, has not been incorporated. The Supreme Court has also not incorporated the Seventh Amendment, which protects the right to a jury trial in civil cases.

27.question: According to the Constitution, who determines voter eligibility requirements?
choices: The president
Congress
State legislatures
Federal administrative agencies
27.initial_response: The Constitution does not explicitly address voter eligibility requirements. However, the Supreme Court has ruled that the states have the authority to determine voter eligibility requirements.

28.question: The difference between a pardon and a reprieve is
choices: a pardon lasts 10 years, while a reprieve lasts one year
a reprieve grants a release from legal punishment, while a pardon postpones it
a pardon grants a release from legal punishment while a reprieve postpones it
only state governors can issue pardons
28.initial_response: that a pardon is an act of forgiveness from the president or governor that cancels the punishment for a crime, while a reprieve is a postponement of a sentence.

29.question: Two related cases that focused on the right to privacy for all American citizens were
choices: Near v. Minnesota and New York Times v. Sullivan
Texas v. Johnson and Morse v. Frederick
Thornhill v. Alabama and Cox v. New Hampshire
Griswold v. Connecticut and Roe v. Wade.
29.initial_response:
Roe v. Wade and Griswold v. Connecticut.

Roe v. Wade was a 1973 Supreme Court case that ruled that a woman's right to an abortion was protected under the right to privacy. Griswold v. Connecticut was a 1965 Supreme Court case that ruled that a married couple's right to use contraception was protected under the right to privacy.

30.question: The swift adoption of the Bill of Rights in the years following ratification of the Constitution demonstrates the
choices: Framers' unqualified commitment to individual rights
small states' determination to receive equal representation in the legislature
Northern states' support for abolitionism
states' fears of an overpowerful national government
30.initial_response:
founders’ understanding that the Bill of Rights was not a new concept, but rather a reaffirmation of the rights that the people already possessed.

The Bill of Rights was not a new concept, but rather a reaffirmation of the rights that the people already possessed. The founders understood that the Bill of Rights was necessary to protect the people from the government, and they were swift in its adoption.

31.question: A Supreme Court that demonstrates a willingness to change public policy and alter judicial precedent is said to be engaging in
choices: judicial activism
due process
judicial restraint
ex post facto lawmaking

32.question: The opposition of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the National Association of Women Lawyers (NAWL), and the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations (AFL-CIO) to Samuel Alito's 2006 nomination to the Supreme Court is an example of
choices: realignment
coalition building
impeachment
a recall election
32.initial_response: the opposition of liberal groups to the nomination of a conservative judge.

33.question: When the Founders met in 1787 to write the Constitution, their primary objective was to
choices: establish a bill of rights that would protect citizens from the government
create a national court system for hearing disputes between citizens of different states
return to the states those powers that the Articles of Confederation had given to the central government
replace the weak central government created by the Articles of Confederation with a stronger one
33.initial_response:
create a federal government that would be strong enough to protect the nation from foreign enemies but not so powerful that it would threaten the rights of the people.

The Founders believed that the best way to achieve this balance was to divide the government’s power between the national government and the state governments. The Constitution does this by creating a system of “checks and balances” between the three branches of the federal government (the executive, legislative, and judicial branches) and between the federal government and the state governments.

The Constitution also protects the rights of the people by guaranteeing certain basic rights, such as freedom of speech and religion, in the First Amendment.

34.question: A constitutional amendment would be required to ban flag burning because that activity is currently protected by the right to
choices: due process
assembly
free exercise of religion
free speech
34.initial_response:
free speech.

The Supreme Court has ruled that flag burning is a form of protected speech under the First Amendment. In the 1989 case Texas v. Johnson, the Court ruled that a state law prohibiting flag burning was unconstitutional. The Court reasoned that the flag is a symbol of the nation, and that burning it is a form of political expression.

In order to ban flag burning, a constitutional amendment would be required to overturn the Supreme Court's ruling in Texas v. Johnson. Such an amendment would likely be difficult to pass, as it would need to be approved by two-thirds of both the House and the Senate, and then ratified by three-fourths of the states.

35.question: To which characteristic of American government does the term "federalism" refer?
choices: The system of checks and balances within the national government
The power of the Supreme Court to review the constitutionality of laws
The Bill of Rights' protection of the rights of the accused
The division and sharing of power between the national and state governments
35.initial_response: The term "federalism" refers to the characteristic of American government in which the national government and the state governments share power.

36.question: Given the structure of the electoral college system, presidential candidates tend to
choices: avoid battleground states and focus their campaigns on "safe" states
campaign more heavily in states with large populations
spend more television advertising money in the Plains States
campaign extensively in states that heavily favor one party over the other
36.initial_response:
focus on winning the most electoral votes

The structure of the electoral college system means that presidential candidates need to focus on winning the most electoral votes. This is because the number of electoral votes a state has is based on the size of its population. Therefore, the candidate who wins the most electoral votes is typically the one who wins the election.

37.question: Filibusters are less likely to occur in the House of Representatives than in the Senate because
choices: Senate decorum forbids one senator from attempting to stop another's speech
the House meets for substantially fewer hours per day than does the Senate
Senate sessions, unlike House sessions, are open to the public
debate in the House is in most instances strictly regulated by the rules
37.initial_response:
the House of Representatives has a rule that allows a simple majority to end debate on a bill.

The Senate has a rule that requires a supermajority of 60 votes to end debate on a bill, which makes it easier for a minority of Senators to filibuster a bill.

38.question: When the Democratic Party pursues liberal social policies, it is most likely to alienate which of its traditional bases?
choices: People holding advanced academic degrees
Northeastern city dwellers
Southerners
Jewish Americans
38.initial_response: The Democratic Party's traditional bases are its supporters among organized labor, racial minorities, and young people. When the party pursues liberal social policies, it is most likely to alienate its supporters among organized labor and racial minorities.

39.question: The practice of drawing congressional district lines in an attempt to give one party a benefit over another is referred to as
choices: front-loading
prior restraint
reapportionment
gerrymandering

40.question: The line-item veto was found unconstitutional because
choices: it gave executive powers to the legislature
it gave legislative powers to the bureaucracy
it gave legislative powers to the president
it delegated too many powers to the states
40.initial_response: it gave the president too much power.

41.question: Why do political scientists identify the presidential elections of Franklin Roosevelt in 1932 and Richard Nixon in 1968 as well as the midterm election of 1994 as "critical elections"?
choices: The issues at stake in those elections were more important than in most elections.
Those elections saw major shifts in party alignment that would last for decades.
Minority voters played a key role in deciding the winners of those elections.
Those elections took place during wartime.
41.initial_response: A critical election is one in which the winning party's victory signals a lasting realignment in the electorate. The election of Franklin Roosevelt in 1932 signaled a realignment in which the Democratic Party became the majority party in the United States. The election of Richard Nixon in 1968 signaled a realignment in which the Republican Party became the majority party in the United States. The midterm election of 1994 signaled a realignment in which the Republican Party became the majority party in the United States Congress.

42.question: House members are more concerned about their committee assignments than are senators because
choices: House members may serve on only one committee at a time
Senate committees have relatively little power to alter legislation
bills in the Senate must pass through all committees before reaching the floor
the rules make it extremely difficult for representatives to influence legislation on the House floor
42.initial_response:
they have less power.

The majority of House members are more concerned about their committee assignments than are senators because they have less power. This is due to the fact that the Senate has more power than the House, and thus senators are able to choose their committee assignments more easily.

43.question: The primary goal of the Gramm-Rudman Acts of 1985 and 1987 was to
choices: strengthen the military
increase funding for social programs
reduce the federal deficit
limit the president's ability to conduct foreign policy

44.question: The Voting Rights Act of 1965
choices: granted women the right to vote
banned race-based discrimination
granted African-Americans the right to vote
suspended the use of literacy tests at voting centers
44.initial_response:
The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is a landmark piece of federal legislation in the United States that prohibits racial discrimination in voting. It was signed into law by President Lyndon B. Johnson on August 6, 1965, and Congress later amended the Act five times to expand its protections.

The Voting Rights Act has been credited with dramatically increasing the number of minority voters in the United States. In the 2012 presidential election, for example, African Americans, Latinos, and Asian Americans voted at higher rates than whites for the first time in history.

The Act has also been used to challenge a number of state and local voting practices and procedures that were found to be discriminatory.

The Voting Rights Act is set to expire in 2032 unless it is renewed by Congress.

45.question: In the House of Representatives, the Rules Committee
choices: determines both the rules of the House and conditions for legislative process
plays a pivotal role in the management of the Library of Congress
has jurisdiction over fisheries and wildlife
determines what behavior is deemed ethical in the House
45.initial_response:
is a committee of the United States House of Representatives responsible for the rules of the House.

The current chairman of the House Rules Committee is James McGovern, and the ranking member is Tom Cole.

46.question: When an appeal is made to the Supreme Court, the court usually
choices: refuses to hear the appeal
declares a mistrial
orders the lower court to retry the case
rules in favor of the defendant
46.initial_response:
hears the case if it involves a question of federal law or if the case is between two or more states. The court may also hear cases in which the United States is a party or in which a state is a party and the validity of a federal law is in question.

The Supreme Court may also choose to hear cases that have been decided by a lower court if the case is of great public importance or if the lower court’s decision is in conflict with the decisions of other lower courts.

47.question: Members of Congress are allowed to mail letters to their constituents at the government's expense because of
choices: gerrymandering
pork-barrel legislation
the Sixteenth Amendment
the franking privilege
47.initial_response:
the franking privilege.

The franking privilege is a privilege that allows members of Congress to send letters to their constituents at the government's expense. The privilege is granted by the Constitution and has been in effect since the early days of the Republic. The privilege is used primarily for official business, but members of Congress can also use it for personal correspondence.

48.question: The idea that the Bill of Rights applies to both federal and state governments by means of the Fourteenth Amendment is called
choices: mandamus
habeas corpus
strict constructionism
the doctrine of incorporation
48.initial_response:
the incorporation doctrine.

The incorporation doctrine is the idea that the Bill of Rights applies to both federal and state governments by means of the Fourteenth Amendment.

49.question: If no presidential candidate receives a majority of the electoral college vote, then who becomes the president?
choices: The candidate who wins the popular national vote
The incumbent vice president of the United States
Whomever is selected by the United States Supreme Court
The candidate who wins the majority of votes in the House
49.initial_response: If no presidential candidate receives a majority of the electoral college vote, then the House of Representatives elects the president.

50.question: Unlike in a closed primary election, in an open primary election
choices: voters select the winner by caucus instead of by individual ballots
the election results are not binding
any registered voter may participate, regardless of party affiliation
voters may register to vote on the day of the election
50.initial_response:
, any voter may vote in any party's primary election, regardless of the voter's affiliation with that party. The voter may only vote in the primary of a single party.

In an open primary election, the voter may only vote in the primary of a single party.

51.question: Every ten years, the majority of state legislatures are responsible for
choices: redrawing congressional district boundaries
electing a new state governor
evaluating the physical accessibility of polling venues
deciding where to construct new elementary schools
51.initial_response:
redrawing congressional districts.

The process of redrawing congressional districts is known as redistricting.

52.question: The spoils system of awarding civil service jobs was replaced by the merit system as a result of the
choices: Truman Doctrine
Fair Labor Standards Act of 1961
National Industrial Recovery Act
Pendleton Act of 1883
52.initial_response:
Pendleton Act

The Pendleton Act was passed in 1883 and it established the Civil Service Commission and it prohibited political assessments for most federal jobs.

53.question: The term "iron triangle" refers to the interrelationship of the
choices: president, Congress, and the Supreme Court
electorate, Congress, and political action committees
local, state, and federal governments
federal bureaucracy, congressional committees, and lobbyists
53.initial_response:
three branches of government in the United States. The three branches are the executive, legislative, and judicial branches. The iron triangle is the relationship between these three branches.

The iron triangle is the relationship between the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government in the United States. This relationship is one of interdependence and cooperation. Each branch needs the others to function properly.

The executive branch is responsible for carrying out the laws of the country. The president is the head of the executive branch. The president appoints the heads of the various executive departments, such as the Department of State and the Department of Defense. The president also has the power to veto legislation passed by Congress.

The legislative branch is responsible for making the laws of the country. The Congress is the legislative branch. Congress is made up of the Senate and the House of Representatives. Senators and Representatives are elected by the people of their states. The Congress has the power to override a presidential veto with a two-thirds vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

The judicial branch is responsible for interpreting the laws of the country. The Supreme Court is the judicial branch. The Supreme Court is made up of nine justices who are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate. The Supreme Court has the power to strike down laws that it finds to be unconstitutional.

54.question: An inherent power of the president is the power to
choices: appoint a nominee for the U.S. Supreme Court
negotiate a treaty with another country
declare a state of emergency following a natural disaster
veto a bill passed by the U.S. Congress
54.initial_response: The inherent power of the president is the power to veto legislation.

55.question: The Supreme Court has used the Fourteenth Amendment to apply portions of the Bill of Rights to state law by citing the amendment's
choices: prohibition on unreasonable search and seizures
due process clause
guarantee of privacy rights
abolition of slavery
55.initial_response:
Due Process Clause.

The Fourteenth Amendment has also been used to protect voting rights, to overturn racial segregation laws, and to establish the one-person, one-vote principle.

56.question: Political efficacy refers to the idea that
choices: political parties can provide a check to the political influence wielded by corporations
individuals believe that they can influence the government through participation in the democratic process
the system of checks and balances ensures that the government is both efficient and productive
politicians have a duty to inform their constituents about the democratic process
56.initial_response:
people have the ability to influence the political process. Political efficacy has been shown to be a strong predictor of political participation.

Political efficacy has two components:

1. Internal political efficacy – the belief that one’s own actions can influence the political process

2. External political efficacy – the belief that the political system is responsive to the public

57.question: A member of the president's cabinet is said to have "gone native" when that cabinet member
choices: resigns to take a position as a consultant to lobbying groups
cedes control of his or her department to lifelong bureaucrats within the department
places his or her department's priorities above the president's
accepts bribes or expensive favors from businesses regulated by his or her department
57.initial_response:
begins to identify more with the president's political opponents than with the president and his or her own party.

The term "gone native" is often used in a negative way to describe a cabinet member who is no longer loyal to the president.

58.question: While best known for protecting freedom of speech and religion, the First Amendment also protects Americans' right to
choices: due process of the law in any criminal case
retain personal property unless justly compensated by the government
not be subjected to excessive fines or unusual punishment
petition the government for a redress of grievances
58.initial_response:
"peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."

The First Amendment is the first of the 10 amendments that make up the Bill of Rights.

The First Amendment protects Americans' rights to freedom of religion, speech, press, petition and assembly.

The First Amendment was adopted on December 15, 1791, as part of the Bill of Rights.

The First Amendment states: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."

The amendment was written to ensure that the government could not establish an official religion, and to protect the free exercise of religion.

The amendment also protects Americans' right to free speech, press and assembly.

The amendment has been interpreted to protect other rights as well, including the right to privacy and the right to due process.

59.question: Considered as a single group, the Small Business Administration, the Small Business committees in the House and Senate, and small business advocacy groups are an example of
choices: an iron triangle
a conference committee
a regulatory agency
dual federalism

60.question: A writ of certiorari from the Supreme Court indicates that the Court
choices: will review a lower court decision
has rendered a decision on a case
has decided not to hear an appeal
will recess until the end of the calendar year
60.initial_response: has decided to hear a case. The writ is a formal request to the lower court to send the records of the case to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court grants or denies the writ, and if it grants the writ, it hears the case.

61.question: An example of a categorical grant would be
choices: money loaned by the federal government to cities to fund school maintenance
money given by the federal government to states without conditions
money loaned by the federal government to a private company to prevent it from failing
money given by the federal government to states to fund Head Start early education programs
61.initial_response:
an award to support a specific class of project, research, or innovative idea using a particular methodology or approach.

A categorical grant is a type of grant that is awarded to support a specific class of project, research, or innovative idea using a particular methodology or approach.

62.question: When the Supreme Court decides to take a case on appeal it
choices: issues a writ of habeas corpus
issues a writ of certiorari
issues amicus curiae briefs
engages in judicial review
62.initial_response:
is not required to give a reason for its decision.

The Supreme Court is not required to give a reason for its decision to take a case on appeal. The court may choose to do so, however, if it believes that its decision will provide guidance to lower courts or the parties involved in the case.

63.question: Congress has attempted to protect independent regulatory agencies from political influence by requiring that each agency
choices: be led by a group of commissioners representing both major political parties
plan policy cooperatively with the appropriate congressional committees
reapply for funding at the end of each fiscal year
submit all planned policy changes to the president for approval
63.initial_response:
have a multi-member commission.

The Federal Reserve Board is an example of an independent regulatory agency.

64.question: The line-item veto was ruled unconstitutional because it
choices: violated the legislative process by which bills become laws
allowed Congress to eliminate sections of legislation without a two-thirds majority
gave states the ability to override federal legislation
empowered Congress to nullify executive actions
64.initial_response: gave the president too much power.

65.question: The Reorganization Plan 1 of 1939 and Executive Order 8248 allow the president to select the staff for the
choices: Peace Corps
White House Office
Senate Committee on Appropriations
Cabinet
65.initial_response:
Executive Office of the President.

The Reorganization Plan 1 of 1939 and Executive Order 8248 allow the president to select the staff for the Executive Office of the President.

66.question: Failed felony prosecutions at the state level are sometimes retried at the federal level
choices: on appeal by state prosecutors
under the "double jeopardy" provision of the Constitution
because new evidence has voided the state-level verdict
as civil liberties violations
66.initial_response:
.

The federal government has the power to prosecute crimes that occur on federal property, such as national parks, and crimes that cross state lines, such as drug trafficking and kidnapping. The federal government also has the power to prosecute crimes that are related to federal agencies, such as fraud against the Social Security Administration or the U.S. Postal Service.

67.question: Compared with political parties in countries such as England and Israel, both of which have multiparty systems, American political parties are
choices: less interested in influencing the outcome of elections
less clearly identified with consistent political ideologies
less effective at raising money from political supporters
better able to reflect the goals of their entire constituencies
67.initial_response:
less ideologically cohesive.

In the United States, there are two major political parties, the Democratic Party and the Republican Party. These parties are often described as being more ideologically cohesive than parties in other countries with multiparty systems. For example, in the United Kingdom, the Labour Party is considered to be more left-wing than the Conservative Party, while in Israel, the Likud Party is considered to be more right-wing than the Labor Party.

68.question: Why has network news coverage become less diverse in recent years?
choices: Decreasing liberal bias in the news media
Increasing visibility for individual candidates on TV
Increasing concentration of ownership in the news media
Decreasing cost of political ads on TV
68.initial_response:
There are a number of reasons why network news coverage has become less diverse in recent years. One reason is that the network news industry has become increasingly consolidated, with a few large companies owning most of the major networks. This consolidation has led to a decrease in the number of news outlets, which in turn has led to less diversity in coverage.

Another reason for the decrease in diversity is the increasing cost of news production. With the rise of digital media, news organizations have been forced to cut costs, and one way they have done this is by reducing the number of reporters and editors. This has led to a decrease in the number of stories being covered, and as a result, the coverage has become less diverse.

Finally, the network news industry has been slow to adapt to the changing demographics of the United States. The population is becoming increasingly diverse, but the network news industry has not kept pace. As a result, the coverage has become less representative of the country as a whole.

69.question: Politicians and political reporters are natural adversaries; the adversarial nature of their relationship, however, is tempered by the fact that
choices: younger politicians who are more comfortable with the media are gradually displacing older politicians
government regulations on interaction between the two groups are very strict
each group is dependent on the other to perform its job effectively
very few media outlets will cover a story that is embarrassing to a political leader
69.initial_response:
they are both in the business of politics. Politicians need reporters to get their message out, and reporters need politicians to provide them with stories.

The relationship between politicians and political reporters is often adversarial. Politicians need reporters to get their message out, and reporters need politicians to provide them with stories. The adversarial nature of their relationship is tempered by the fact that they are both in the business of politics.

70.question: Both the War Powers Act of 1974 and the Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 represent efforts by Congress to limit the powers of the
choices: Joint Chiefs of Staff
House Ways and Means Committee
Central Intelligence Agency
president
70.initial_response:
presidency.

The War Powers Act was passed in response to the Vietnam War, and it sought to limit the president's ability to commit troops to combat without the approval of Congress. The Budget and Impoundment Control Act was passed in response to President Nixon's decision to impound funds that had been appropriated by Congress. This act sought to limit the president's ability to unilaterally decide how to spend federal funds.

choices: negotiate treaties
collect taxes
establish a federal judiciary
enforce its laws
71.initial_response:
:

1. Declare war
2. Make treaties
3. Raise an army and navy
4. Coin money
5. Borrow money
6. Regulate interstate and foreign commerce

72.question: The Framers of the Constitution sought to insulate the Senate from public opinion by
choices: restricting Senate membership to those who previously served in the House of Representatives
delegating the responsibility for electing senators to the state legislatures
requiring all spending bills to originate in the House of Representatives
empowering the Senate to provide advice and consent to the executive branch
72.initial_response: making it a more deliberative body than the House of Representatives. The Senate was designed to be a more exclusive body than the House, giving each state two senators regardless of population. The Senate was also designed to give each state an equal vote, regardless of population. The Senate was also given the power to approve presidential appointments and treaties. The Senate was not designed to be a rubber stamp for the president, but rather a check on the president's power.

73.question: The majority of Supreme Court justices
choices: are appointed by presidents of the same political party
have no prior judicial experience
switch party affiliation during their term
stay on the court for only a decade
73.initial_response:
are white men

74.question: A presidential plurality victory occurs when
choices: the winning candidate receives less than 50 percent of the popular vote
candidates receive an equal number of electoral votes and the popular vote determines the winner
the Senate declares the formal winner
the winning candidate receives more than 50% of the popular vote
74.initial_response:
a candidate wins more electoral votes than any other candidate, but does not win an outright majority of the electoral votes.

A presidential plurality victory occurs when a candidate wins more electoral votes than any other candidate, but does not win an outright majority of the electoral votes. This can happen if there are three or more candidates running for president, and one of them wins a plurality of the electoral votes but not a majority. In this case, the candidate who wins the most electoral votes is said to have won a plurality victory.

75.question: In Gideon v. Wainwright, the Supreme Court ruled that criminal defendants in state cases have the right
choices: to representation by an attorney
not to incriminate themselves
to a speedy trial
not to be punished excessively
75.initial_response:
to an attorney.

In Gideon v. Wainwright, the Supreme Court ruled that criminal defendants in state cases have the right to an attorney.

76.question: People who join a political party other than the one to which their parents belong most often do so because of
choices: peer pressure
economic issues
religious beliefs
pressure from their employers
76.initial_response: the party's stance on a particular issue.

77.question: The right of American citizens to petition the government for a redress of grievances is protected under the
choices: First Amendment
Second Amendment
Third Amendment
Eighth Amendment
77.initial_response:
First Amendment of the Constitution. This right allows citizens to bring attention to issues or problems they believe the government should address. The government is not required to act on these petitions, but it must allow them to be made.

The right to petition is often used by groups or individuals who feel they have been wronged by the government. For example, citizens may petition the government to change a law they believe is unjust. They may also petition the government to take action on an issue, such as environmental protection or civil rights.

The right to petition is not absolute. The government may place restrictions on how petitions are made, such as requiring that they be in writing. The government may also limit the topics that can be petitioned, such as by prohibiting petitions that are frivolous or that could lead to violence.

78.question: In the majority of cases, federal programs are implemented by
choices: private businesses working as subcontractors to the government
state and local governments, by means of federal funding
Congress, through the local offices of its elected representatives
the federal courts, by means of criminal prosecutions
78.initial_response:
the states.

In the majority of cases, federal programs are implemented by the states. This is done through a process called federalism, which is the sharing of power between the federal government and the states. Federalism allows the federal government to create national laws and policies, while the states are responsible for implementing these laws and policies.

79.question: How many votes in the Senate must a presidential nominee to the Supreme Court receive in order to be confirmed?
choices: Forty percent
Fifty-one percent
Fifty-five percent
Sixty percent

Judiciary

82.question: The rules governing the electoral college make it especially important for presidential candidates to
choices: win as many states as possible, regardless of the size of the states
spend most of their time campaigning in the South
campaign most aggressively among those who will be chosen as electors
concentrate their campaign efforts on "battleground" states
82.initial_response:
focus on winning the most electoral votes, rather than the most popular votes.

The rules of the electoral college are that the President of the United States is not elected by popular vote, but by electoral vote. The President is not elected by the majority of the people, but by the majority of the electoral votes. The President is not elected by the majority of the people in each state, but by the majority of the electoral votes in each state.

The rules of the electoral college make it especially important for presidential candidates to focus on winning the most electoral votes, rather than the most popular votes. This is because the President is not elected by the majority of the people, but by the majority of the electoral votes. The President is not elected by the majority of the people in each state, but by the majority of the electoral votes in each state.

introduce bills to the floor of Congress
address Congress during its debate on bills
vote on acts of Congress

veto legislation.

choices: Thomas Hobbes
Niccolo Macchiavelli

John Locke

85.question: Divided government frequently results in
choices: reapportionment of voting districts
amendments to the Constitution
conflict between states and the federal government
delays in the confirmation of those nominated to be ambassadors
85.initial_response:
gridlock.

Divided government is a situation in which one party controls the executive branch while another party controls one or both of the legislative branches. This can lead to gridlock, where the two parties are unable to pass any legislation because they cannot agree on anything.

86.question: Federal election laws require that, in
choices: an area that has a substantial community of non-English speakers, voters be provided with ballots in their native language
an electoral district that has historically low voter turnout, polling places be open for longer than the typical work day
a state with a budget deficit, a tax be collected from each voter to pay for the cost of the election
a region with racial diversity, congressional district lines be drawn to guarantee that at least one elected congressperson be of a racial minority
86.initial_response:
order to be eligible to receive federal matching funds, a candidate must agree to abide by spending limits.

The spending limits for the 2016 presidential election are $2,700 per person for the primary election and $2,700 per person for the general election.

87.question: The absence of a political party solely dedicated to labor and working class issues in the United States
choices: proves U.S. politicians are not concerned about serving working-class constituencies
is the result of government restrictions placed on the political activities of labor unions
reflects the difficulty of unifying a party around a single issue in a "winner-take-all" format
demonstrates that, in the United States, most political issues regarding workers have been decided in the workers' favor
87.initial_response:
is a major political problem.

The United States has a long history of labor and working class issues. The country was founded on the principle of "equal opportunity for all," but this ideal has never been fully realized. Throughout the country's history, there have been periods of great prosperity and periods of great hardship for the working class. The Gilded Age was a time of great wealth inequality, as the top 1% of Americans held more than half of the country's wealth. The Great Depression was a time of great economic hardship, as millions of Americans lost their jobs and their homes.

The labor movement has always been a force for change in the United States. The labor movement was instrumental in winning the eight-hour work day, the weekend, and other important protections for workers. The labor movement has also been a force for political change, helping to elect progressive presidents like Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson.

However, the labor movement has been in decline for many years. Union membership has declined from a high of 35% in the 1950s to just 11% today. This decline has been caused by a number of factors, including the decline of manufacturing jobs, the rise of the service economy, and the anti-union policies of many corporations.

The decline of the labor movement has had a profound impact on American politics. The labor movement was once a powerful political force, but its decline has left working-class Americans without a strong political voice. This has had a number of negative consequences, including the rise of right-wing populism, the election of Donald Trump, and the continued decline of the middle class.

The solution to this problem is the creation of a new political party that is dedicated to labor and working-class issues. This party would fight for the interests of working-class Americans and seek to restore the power of the labor movement. Such a party would be a powerful force for good in American politics and could help to create a more just and prosperous society.

88.question: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was passed to reinforce the
choices: presidential veto
system of checks and balances
states' power to challenge federal regulation
Fourteenth Amendment
88.initial_response:
Fourteenth Amendment and protect the civil rights of African Americans.

The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was passed to reinforce the Fourteenth Amendment and protect the civil rights of African Americans. The act made it illegal to discriminate against someone based on their race, color, religion, or national origin. The act also created the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which is responsible for investigating complaints of discrimination in the workplace.

89.question: The Supreme Court's decision in Miranda v. Arizona was based mainly on the
choices: Constitutional prohibition of ex post facto laws
incorporation of the Fifth Amendment through the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
Eighth Amendment restriction against cruel and unusual punishment
abolition of slavery by the Thirteenth Amendment
89.initial_response:
Fifth Amendment.

The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution protects citizens from self-incrimination. The Miranda decision requires law enforcement officers to inform criminal suspects of their Fifth Amendment rights before questioning them.
